Michele here’s the issue I’m seeing with the tables currently implemented in the RTE. I realize this is a major UI challenge to solve but I think it can be solved.

So what I see happening every now and again is users resize columns in their tables.  The columns get automatically set at px values.

Makes sense but not for the majority of situations. Would be better if it would do percents. Seems like the logic already has to be in there to be able to calculate the px values anyways, might as well use percents.

So that’s problem Uno.

Problem Dos. the tables it generates are not very friendly to screen readers. I realize this is a tougher problem to solve but I still think it’s possible to provide a UI for it.
i love that you are all about accessibility, <@U7SL518D6>

The key things that would be nice for the table interface to have - a way to specify a table head, table body (tfooter is more optional)

I realize getting marketers to use this properly might be a pain, but maybe there are ways to encourage it through the UI, like  by default treating the first row as headers, unless the user treats it otherwise.

Then each cell can be  toggled between being a th or a td (some visual indicator could be used in the UI)

Thats kinda the minimum. if we really wanted to make this good a gold standard would be to implement a way for users to set the scope on th elements. default for first row would be `col`
I realize it’s maybe hard to pitch all the dev time to the higher ups for something that is hard for them to visually see and understand the benefits of.
I would even be cool with there being a new module or custom field type for this.

instead of rich text, if rich text were too hard to modify.


The way I see it, marketers aren’t going to learn to make things accessible, that’s the developers and maybe a specialists job. Developers have the problem of it’s hard to sell a client on additional hours of work especially for things they can’t see or understand.(especially if they think they can make a table themselves because of the RTE)

and most companies are not aware enough of accessibility needs to have anyone to do that kind of work.

If we can make it easy for anyone to go into the editor and make a table that isn’t an awful experience responsively or accessibility wise, then huzzah. We will not just make the web better but help prevent HS clients from getting sued over accessibility.
